Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: I was at my desk, the soft glow of the evening sun filtering through the window, when my phone buzzed insistently. It was a message from my manager: “Please confirm the meeting details with our partner ASAP.” I glanced at the clock. It was almost time for my daily puja, the moment I set aside to light a lamp and offer prayers at my home altar. As a Hindu, this ritual grounds me, a sacred pause in my day that I rarely compromise. But as a colleague, I’m expected to be responsive, especially when leadership is waiting on me. My inbox pinged again, the subject line urgent. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—my team counting on my promptness, my faith calling me to pause and connect. I stared at the flickering lamp, feeling the tension coil inside me, torn between the demands of my work and the pull of my spiritual practice.
